item.title: Notes on Lean prover
item.description: Inductive type Inductive families inductive vector (α : Type u) : nat → Type u | nil {} : vector zero | cons {n : ℕ} (a : α) (v : vector n) : vector (succ n) In the declaration of inductive families, any argument in the type declaration before the colon is a type parameter. They are also implicitly present in the constructor declarations. The arguments after the colon are indices and are explicitly specified in the constructor declaration to indicate which member of the type family is being constructed.

item.title: Surfaces overview
item.description: Topological classification of surfaces Dimension/connectedness. Additional structure: smoothness and manifolds. It can be shown that every surface is a smooth 2-manifold and that every smooth 2-manifold can be embedded in \(\mathbb{R}^4\) . Orientability. All orientable surfaces can be embedded in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) . There are nonorientable surfaces, such as \(\mathbb{RP}^2\) (or the Klein bottle), that can’t be embedded in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) . Genus. Triangulation \(\rightarrow\) cell complexes \(\rightarrow\) normal form. Describe the fundamental group of a connected compact orientable surface.

item.title: Poncelet closure theorem 3
item.description: Curves and genus We are working with complex projective curves. Show elliptic curves have genus 1. Show genus 1 curves are elliptic curves. Algebraic object Let \(C,D\) be two smooth conics in \(\mathbb{CP}^2\) , with \(\#(C\cap D)=4\) . Let \(D^*\) be the dual curve, i.e. lines that are tangent to \(D\) . Show \(D^*\) is also a smooth conic. Define \(E(C, D)\stackrel{\triangle}{=}\{(P, L)\mid P\in C, L\in D^*, P\in L\}\subset C \times D^*\) .

item.title: Poncelet closure theorem 2
item.description: Jacobian invariant for circles Consider two circles C,C’ with radii R, r. Let the distance between their centers be d. Define k as following: $$ k^2 = \frac{4dR}{\sqrt{(R+d)^2-r^2}} $$ Choose the polar coordinates with origin at the center of the circle C. Let the polar angle of a point \(P(\phi)\) on C be \(2\phi\) . Let \(P_0=P(\phi_0)\) and \(P_1=P(\phi_1)\) be two points on C such that the line \(P_0 P_1\) is tangent to the circle C’ at the point Q.
